1 𝒟 ϵ 1↙ ↘ ϵ 2 F 1(1 𝒞) ⟶f(1 𝒞) F 2(1 𝒞). \array{ && 1_{\mathcal{D}} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\epsilon_1}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\epsilon_2}} \\ F_1(1_{\mathcal{C}}) &&\underset{f(1_{\mathcal{C}})}{\longrightarrow}&& F_2(1_{\mathcal{C}}) } \,.

We write MonFun(𝒞,𝒟)MonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the resulting category of lax monoidal functors between monoidal categories 𝒞\mathcal{C} and 𝒟\mathcal{D}, similarly BraidMonFun(𝒞,𝒟)BraidMonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the category of braided monoidal functors between braided monoidal categories, and SymMonFun(𝒞,𝒟)SymMonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the category of braided monoidal functors between symmetric monoidal categories.

Remark

In the literature the term “monoidal functor” often refers by default to what in def. 30 is called a strong monoidal functor. But for the purpose of the discussion of functors with smash product below, it is crucial to admit the generality of lax monoidal functors.

If (𝒞,⊗ 𝒞,1 𝒞)(\mathcal{C},\otimes_{\mathcal{C}}, 1_{\mathcal{C}}) and (𝒟,⊗ 𝒟,1 𝒟)(\mathcal{D},\otimes_{\mathcal{D}}, 1_{\mathcal{D}} ) are symmetric monoidal categories (def. 28) then a braided monoidal functor (def. 30) between them is often called a symmetric monoidal functor.

Proposition

For 𝒞⟶F𝒟⟶Gℰ\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D} \overset{G}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{E} two composable lax monoidal functors (def. 30) between monoidal categories, then their composite F∘GF \circ G becomes a lax monoidal functor with structure morphisms

ϵ G∘F:1 ℰ⟶ϵ GG(1 𝒟)⟶G(ϵ F)G(F(1 𝒞)) \epsilon^{G\circ F} \;\colon\; 1_{\mathcal{E}} \overset{\epsilon^G}{\longrightarrow} G(1_{\mathcal{D}}) \overset{G(\epsilon^F)}{\longrightarrow} G(F(1_{\mathcal{C}}))

and

μ c 1,c 2 G∘F:G(F(c 1))⊗ ℰG(F(c 2))⟶μ F(c 1),F(c 2) GG(F(c 1)⊗ 𝒟F(c 2))⟶G(μ c 1,c 2 F)G(F(c 1⊗ 𝒞c 2)). \mu^{G \circ F}_{c_1,c_2} \;\colon\; G(F(c_1)) \otimes_{\mathcal{E}} G(F(c_2)) \overset{\mu^{G}_{F(c_1), F(c_2)}}{\longrightarrow} G( F(c_1) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(c_2) ) \overset{G(\mu^F_{c_1,c_2})}{\longrightarrow} G(F( c_1 \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} c_2 )) \,.

Enriched categories

The plain definition of categories in Def. 1 is phrased in terms of sets. Via Example 1 this assigns a special role to the category Set of all sets, as the “base” on top, or the “cosmos” inside which category theory takes place. For instance, the fact that hom-sets in a plain category are indeed sets, is what makes the hom-functor (Example 9) take values in Set, and this, in turn, governs the form of the all-important Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) and Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2) as statements about presheaves of sets (Example 15).

At the same time, category theory witnesses the utility of abstracting away from concrete choices to their abstract properties that are actually used in constructions. This makes it natural to ask if one could replace the category Set by some other category 𝒱\mathcal{V} which could similarly serve as a “cosmos” inside which category theory may be developed.

Indeed, such 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category theory (see Example 33 below for the terminology) exists, beginning with the concept of 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32 below) and from there directly paralleling, hence generalizing, plain category theory, as long as one assumes the “cosmos” category 𝒱\mathcal{V} to share a minimum of abstract properties with Set (Def. 31 below).

This turns out to be most useful. In fact, the perspective of enriched categories is helpful already when 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set, in which case it reproduces plain category theory (Example 32 below), for instance in that it puts the (co)limits of the special form of (co)ends (Def. 40 below) to the forefront (discussed below).

\,

Definition

(cosmos)

A Bénabou cosmos for enriched category theory, or just cosmos, for short, is a symmetric (Def. 28) closed monoidal category (Def. 29) 𝒱\mathcal{V} which has all limits and colimits.

Example

(examples of cosmoi for enriched category theory)

The following are examples of cosmoi (Def. 31):

  1. Set (Def. 1) equipped with its cartesian closed category-structure (Example 25)

  2. Grpd (Def. 8) equipped with its cartesian closed category-structure (Example 27).

Example

underlying set of an object in a cosmos

Let 𝒱\mathcal{V} be a cosmos (Def. 31), with 1∈𝒱1 \in \mathcal{V} its tensor unit (Def. 26). Then the hom-functor (Def. 9) out of 11

Hom 𝒱(1,−):𝒱⟶Set Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow Set

admits the structure of a lax monoidal functor (Def. 30) to Set, with the latter regarded with its cartesian monoidal structure from Example 25.

Given V∈𝒱V \in \mathcal{V}, we call

Hom 𝒱(1,V)∈Set Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,V) \;\in\; Set

also the underlying set of VV.

Proof

Take the monoidal transformations (eq“MonoidalComponentsOfMonoidalFunctor) to be

Hom 𝒱(1,V 1)×Hom 𝒱(1,V 2)⟶Hom 𝒱(1,V 1⊗V 2) (1→f 1V 1,1→f 2V 2) ↦ (1→≃1⊗1⟶f 1⊗f 2V 1⊗V 2) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_1) \times Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_2) \longrightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_1 \otimes V_2) \\ \big( 1 \overset{f_1}{\to} V_1\;,\; 1 \overset{f_2}{\to} V_2 \big) &\mapsto& \big( 1 \overset{\simeq}{\to} 1 \otimes 1 \overset{f_1 \otimes f_2}{\longrightarrow} V_1 \otimes V_2 \big) }

and take the unit transformation (41)

* ⟶ Hom 𝒱(1,1) \array{ \ast &\longrightarrow& Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,1) }

to pick id 1∈Hom 𝒱(1,1)id_1 \in Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,1).

Example

(underlying set of internal hom is hom-set)*

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let X,Y∈Obj 𝒱X,Y \in Obj_{\mathcal{V}} be two objects. Then the underlying set (Def. 30) of their internal hom [X,Y]∈𝒱[X,Y] \in \mathcal{V} (Def. 29) is the hom-set (Def. 1):

ℋℴ𝓂 𝒱(1,[X,Y])≃Hom 𝒱(X,Y). \mathcal{Hom}_{\mathcal{V}}\left( 1, [X,Y]\right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(X,Y) \,.

This identification is the adjunction isomorphism (10) for the internal hom adjunction (36) followed composed with a unitor (Def. 26).

Definition

(enriched category)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category 𝒞\mathcal{C} is:

  1. a class Obj 𝒞Obj_{\mathcal{C}}, called the class of objects;

  2. for each a,b∈Obj 𝒞a, b\in Obj_{\mathcal{C}}, an object

    𝒞(a,b)∈𝒱, \mathcal{C}(a,b)\in \mathcal{V} \,,

    called the 𝒱\mathcal{V}-object of morphisms between aa and bb;

  3. for each a,b,c∈Obj(𝒞)a,b,c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism in 𝒱\mathcal{V}

    ∘ a,b,c:𝒞(a,b)×𝒞(b,c)⟶𝒞(a,c) \circ_{a,b,c} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b)\times \mathcal{C}(b,c) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(a,c)

    out of the tensor product of hom-objects, called the composition operation;

  4. for each a∈Obj(𝒞)a \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism Id a:*→𝒞(a,a)Id_a \colon \ast \to \mathcal{C}(a,a), called the identity morphism on aa

such that the composition is associative and unital.

If the class Obj 𝒞Obj_{\mathcal{C}} happens to be a set (hence a small set instead of a proper class) then we say the 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category 𝒞\mathcal{C} is small, as in Def. 4.

Example

(Set-enriched categories are plain categories)

An enriched category (Def. 32) over the cosmos 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set, as in Example 29, is the same as a plain category (Def. 1).

Example

(underlying category of an enriched category)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32).

Using the lax monoidal structure (Def. 30) on the hom functor (Example 30)

Hom 𝒱(1,−):𝒱⟶Set Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow Set

out of the tensor unit 1∈𝒞1 \in \mathcal{C} this induces a Set-enriched category |𝒞|\vert \mathcal{C}\vert with hence an ordinary category (Example 32), with

  • Obj |𝒞|≔Obj 𝒞Obj_{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert} \;\coloneqq\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}};

  • Hom |𝒞|(X,Y)≔Hom 𝒱(1,𝒞(X,Y))Hom_{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert}( X, Y ) \;\coloneqq\; Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, \mathcal{C}(X,Y)).

It is in this sense that 𝒞\mathcal{C} is a plain category |𝒞|{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert} equipped with extra structure, and hence an “enriched category”.

The archetypical example is 𝒱\mathcal{V} itself:

Example

(𝒱\mathcal{V} as a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category)

Evert cosmos 𝒞\mathcal{C} (Def. 31) canonically obtains the structure of a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category, def. 32:

the hom-objects are the internal homs

𝓋(X,Y)≔[X,Y] \mathcal{v}(X,Y) \coloneqq [X,Y]

and with composition

[X,Y]×[Y,Z]⟶[X,Z] [X,Y] \times [Y,Z] \longrightarrow [X,Z]

given by the adjunct under the (Cartesian product⊣\dashv internal hom)-adjunction of the evaluation morphisms

X⊗[XmY]⊗[Y,Z]⟶(ev,id)Y⊗[Y,Z]⟶evZ. X \otimes [XmY] \otimes [Y,Z] \overset{(ev, id)}{\longrightarrow} Y \otimes [Y,Z] \overset{ev}{\longrightarrow} Z \,.

The usual construction on categories, such as that of opposite categories (Def. 6) and product categories (Def. 7) have evident enriched analogs

Definition

(enriched opposite category and product category)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos, let 𝒞,𝒟\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32).

  1. The opposite enriched category 𝒞 op\mathcal{C}^{op} is the enriched category with the same objects as 𝒞\mathcal{C}, with hom-objects

    𝒞 op(X,Y)≔𝒞(Y,X) \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Y) \coloneqq \mathcal{C}(Y,X)

    and with composition given by braiding (35) followed by the composition in 𝒞\mathcal{C}:

    𝒞 op(X,Y)⊗𝒞 op(Y,Z)=𝒞(Y,X)⊗𝒞(Z,Y)⟶≃τ𝒞(Z,Y)⊗𝒞(Y,X)⟶∘ Z,Y,X𝒞(Z,X)=𝒞 op(X,Z). \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Y) \otimes \mathcal{C}^{op}(Y,Z) = \mathcal{C}(Y,X) \otimes \mathcal{C}(Z,Y) \underoverset{\simeq}{\tau}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}(Z,Y) \otimes \mathcal{C}(Y,X) \overset{\circ_{Z,Y,X}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}(Z,X) = \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Z) \,.

  2. the enriched product category 𝒞×𝒟\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} is the enriched category whose objects are pairs of objects (c,d)(c,d) with c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} and d∈𝒟d\in \mathcal{D}, whose hom-spaces are the tensor product of the separate hom objects

    (𝒞×𝒟)((c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2))≔𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗𝒟(d 1,d 2) (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1),\;(c_2,d_2) ) \coloneqq \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2)\otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2)

    and whose composition operation is the braiding (35) followed by the tensor product of the separate composition operations:

    (𝒞×𝒟)((c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2))⊗(𝒞×𝒟)((c 2,d 2),(c 3,d 3)) =↓ (𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗𝒟(d 1,d 2))⊗(𝒞(c 2,c 3)⊗𝒟(d 2,d 3)) ↓ ≃ τ (𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗𝒞(c 2,c 3))⊗(𝒟(d 1,d 2)⊗𝒟(d 2,d 3)) ⟶(∘ c 1,c 2,c 3)⊗(∘ d 1,d 2,d 3) 𝒞(c 1,c 3)⊗𝒟(d 1,d 3) ↓ = (𝒞×𝒟)((c 1,d 1),(c 3,d 3)). \array{ (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1), \; (c_2,d_2)) \otimes (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_2,d_2), \; (c_3,d_3)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{=}}\downarrow \\ \left(\mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2)\right) \otimes \left(\mathcal{C}(c_2,c_3) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_2,d_3)\right) \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tau}}_{\mathrlap{\simeq}} \\ \left(\mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{C}(c_2,c_3)\right) \otimes \left( \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_2,d_3)\right) &\overset{ (\circ_{c_1,c_2,c_3}) \otimes (\circ_{d_1,d_2,d_3}) }{\longrightarrow} & \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_3) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_3) \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{=}} \\ && (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1),\; (c_3,d_3)) } \,.
Definition

(enriched functor)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} and 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32).

A 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor from 𝒞\mathcal{C} to 𝒟\mathcal{D}

F:𝒞⟶𝒟 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

is

  1. a function

    F Obj:Obj 𝒞⟶Obj 𝒟 F_{Obj} \;\colon\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}} \longrightarrow Obj_{\mathcal{D}}

    of objects;

  2. for each a,b∈Obj 𝒞a,b \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a morphism in 𝒱\mathcal{V}

    F a,b:𝒞(a,b)⟶𝒟(F 0(a),F 0(b)) F_{a,b} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F_0(a), F_0(b))

    between hom-objects

such that this preserves composition and identity morphisms in the evident sense.

Example

(enriched hom-functor)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32). Then there is a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor out of the enriched product category of 𝒞\mathcal{C} with its enriched opposite category (Def. 33)

𝒞(−,−):𝒞 op×𝒞⟶𝒱 \mathcal{C}(-,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

to 𝒱\mathcal{V}, regarded as a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Example 34), which sends a pair of objects X,Y∈𝒞X,Y \in \mathcal{C} to the hom-object 𝒞(X,Y)∈𝒱\mathcal{C}(X,Y) \in \mathcal{V}, and which acts on morphisms by composition in the evident way.

Example

(enriched presheaves)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32). Then a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34)

F:𝒞⟶𝒱 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

to the archetypical 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category from Example 34 is:

  1. an object F a∈Obj 𝒱F_a \in Obj_{\mathcal{V}} for each object a∈Obj 𝒞a \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}};

  2. a morphism in 𝒱\mathcal{V} of the form

    F a⊗𝒞(a,b)⟶F b F_a \otimes \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow F_b

    for all pairs of objects a,b∈Obj(𝒞)a,b \in Obj(\mathcal{C})

    (this is the adjunct of F a,bF_{a,b} under the adjunction (36) on 𝒱\mathcal{V})

such that composition is respected, in the evident sense.

For every object c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C}, there is an enriched representable functor, denoted

y(c)≔𝒞(c,−) y(c) \;\coloneqq\; \mathcal{C}(c,-)

(where on the right we have the enriched hom-functor from Example 35)

which sends objects to

y(c)(d)=𝒞(c,d)∈𝒱 y(c)(d) = \mathcal{C}(c,d) \in \mathcal{V}

and whose action on morphisms is, under the above identification, just the composition operation in 𝒞\mathcal{C}.

More generally, the following situation will be of interest:

Example

(enriched functor on enriched product category with opposite category)

An 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34) into 𝒱\mathcal{V} (Example 34) out of an enriched product category (Def. 33)

F:𝒞×𝒟⟶𝒱 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

(an “enriched bifunctor”) has component morphisms of the form

F (c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2):𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗𝒟(d 1,d 2)⟶[F 0((c 1,d 1)),F 0((c 2,d 2))]. F_{(c_1,d_1),(c_2,d_2)} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \longrightarrow \big[ F_0((c_1,d_1)),F_0((c_2,d_2)) \big] \,.

By functoriality and under passing to adjuncts (Def. 11) under (36) this is equivalent to two commuting actions

ρ c 1,c 2(d):𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗F 0((c 1,d))⟶F 0((c 2,d)) \rho_{c_1,c_2}(d) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes F_0((c_1,d)) \longrightarrow F_0((c_2,d))

and

ρ d 1,d 2(c):𝒟(d 1,d 2)⊗F 0((c,d 1))⟶F 0((c,d 2)). \rho_{d_1,d_2}(c) \;\colon\; \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \otimes F_0((c,d_1)) \longrightarrow F_0((c,d_2)) \,.

In the special case of a functor out of the enriched product category of some 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category 𝒞\mathcal{C} with its enriched opposite category (def. 33)

F:𝒞 op×𝒞⟶𝒱 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

then this takes the form of a “pullback action” in the first variable

ρ c 2,c 1(d):𝒞(c 1,c 2)⊗F 0((c 2,d))⟶F 0((c 1,d)) \rho_{c_2,c_1}(d) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes F_0((c_2,d)) \longrightarrow F_0((c_1,d))

and a “pushforward action” in the second variable

ρ d 1,d 2(c):𝒞(d 1,d 2)⊗F 0((c,d 1))⟶F 0((c,d 2)). \rho_{d_1,d_2}(c) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(d_1,d_2) \otimes F_0((c,d_1)) \longrightarrow F_0((c,d_2)) \,.
Definition

(enriched natural transformation)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} and 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32) and let

𝒞⟶G⟶F𝒟 \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functors (Def. 34) from 𝒞\mathcal{C} to 𝒟\mathcal{D}.

Then a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched natural transformation

𝒞AA⇓ηAA⟶G⟶F𝒟 \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA}\Downarrow{\mathrlap{\eta}}\phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D}

is

  • for each c∈Obj 𝒞c \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a choice of morphism

    η c:I⟶𝒟(F(c),G(c)) \eta_c \;\colon\; I \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F(c),G(c))

    such that for each pair of objects c,d∈𝒞c,d \in \mathcal{C} the two morphisms (in 𝒱\mathcal{V})

(43)η d∘F(−):𝒞(c,d)≃r𝒞(c,d)⊗I⟶G c,d⊗η c𝒟(G(c),G(d))⊗𝒟(F(c),G(c))⟶∘ F(c),G(c),G(d)𝒟(F(c),G(d)) \eta_d \circ F(-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{r}{\simeq} \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes I \overset{ G_{c,d} \otimes \eta_c }{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(G(c),G(d)) \otimes \mathcal{D}( F(c), G(c) ) \overset{\circ_{F(c), G(c), G(d)}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

and

(44)G(−)∘η c:𝒞(c,d)≃ℓI⊗𝒞(c,d)⟶η d⊗F c,d𝒟(F(d),G(d))⊗𝒟(F(c),F(d))⟶∘ F(c),F(d),G(d)𝒟(F(c),G(d)) G(-) \circ \eta_c \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{\ell}{\simeq} I \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{ \eta_d \otimes F_{c,d} }{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(d), G(d)) \otimes \mathcal{D}(F(c), F(d)) \overset{\circ_{F(c),F(d), G(d)}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

agree.

Example

(functor category of enriched functors)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31) let 𝒞\mathcal{C}, 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32). Then there is a category (Def. 1) of enriched functors (Def. 34), to be denoted

[𝒞,𝒟] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}]

whose objects are the enriched functors 𝒞→F𝒟\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\to} \mathcal{D} and whose morphisms are the enriched natural transformations between these (Def. 35).

In the case that 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set, via Def. 29, with SetSet-enriched categories identified with plain categories via Example 32, this coincides with the functor category from Example 14.

Notice that, at this point, [𝒞,𝒟][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] is a plain category, not itself a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category, unless 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set. But it may be enhanced to one, this is Def. 41 below.

Definition

(tensoring and powering of enriched presheaves)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category, def. 32, with [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] its functor category of enriched functors (Example 38).

  1. Define a functor

    (−)⋅(−):[𝒞,𝒱]×𝒱⟶[𝒞,𝒱] (-)\cdot(-) \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \times \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    by forming objectwise tensor products

    F⋅X:c↦F(c)⊗X. F \cdot X \;\colon\; c \mapsto F(c) \otimes X \,.

    This is called the tensoring of [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] over 𝒱\mathcal{V}.

  2. Define a functor

    (−) (−):𝒱 op×[𝒞,𝒱]⟶[𝒞,𝒱] (-)^{(-)} \;\colon\; \mathcal{V}^{op} \times [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    by forming objectwise internal homs (Def. 29)

    F X:c↦[X,F(c)]. F^X \;\colon\; c \mapsto [X,F(c)] \,.

    This is called the powering of [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] over 𝒱\mathcal{V}.

There is now the following evident generalization of the concept of adjoint functors (Def. 11) from plain category theory to enriched category theory:

Definition

(enriched adjunction)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C}, 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32). Then an adjoint pair of 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functors or enriched adjunction

𝒞⊥⟶R⟵L𝒟 \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is a pair of 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functors (Def. 34), as shown, such that there is a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphism (Def. 35) between enriched hom-functors (Def. 35) of the form

(45)𝒞(L(−),−)≃𝒟(−,R(−)). \mathcal{C}(L(-),-) \;\simeq\; \mathcal{D}(-,R(-)) \,.
Definition

(enriched equivalence of categories)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C}, 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32). Then an equivalence of enriched categories

𝒞AA≃AA⟶R⟵L𝒟 \array{ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{AA} \simeq \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D} }

is a pair of 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functors back and forth, as shown (Def. 34), together with 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphisms (Def. 35) between their composition and the identity functors:

id 𝒟⇒≃R∘LAAAandAAAL∘R⇒≃id 𝒞. id_{\mathcal{D}} \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} R \circ L \phantom{AAA} \text{and} \phantom{AAA} L \circ R \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} id_{\mathcal{C}} \,.

\,

Universal constructions

What makes category theory be theory, as opposed to just a language, is the concept of universal constructions. This refers to the idea of objects with a prescribed property which are universal with this property, in that they “know about” or “subsume” every other object with that same kind of property. Category theory allows to make precise what this means, and then to discover and prove theorems about it.

Universal constructions are all over the place in mathematics. Iteratively finding the universal constructions in a prescribed situation essentially amounts to systematically following the unravelling of the given situation or problem or theory that one is studying.

There are several different formulations of the concept of universal constructions, discussed below:

  • Limits and colimits

  • Ends and coends

  • Left and right Kan extensions

But these three kinds of constructions all turn out to be special cases of each other, hence they really reflect different perspectives on a single topic of universal constructions. In fact, all three are also special cases of the concept of adjunction (Def. 11), thus re-amplifying that category theory is really the theory of adjunctions and hence, if we follow (Lambek 82), of duality.

\,

Limits and colimits

Maybe the most hands-on version of universal constructions are limits (Def. 39 below), which is short for limiting cones (Remark 8 below). The formally dual concept (Example 6) is called colimits (which are hence limits in an opposite category). Other terminology is in use, too:

A\phantom{A} lim⟵\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} lim⟶\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim} A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} limit A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} colimit A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} inverse limit A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} direct limitA\phantom{A}

There is a variety of different kinds of limits/colimits, depending on the diagram shape that they are limiting (co-)cones over. This includes universal constructions known as equalizers, products, fiber products/pullbacks, filtered limits and various others, all of which are basic tools frequently used whenever category theory applies.

A key fact of category theory, regarding limits, is that right adjoints preserve limits and left adjoints preserve colimits (Prop. 25 below). This will be used all the time. A partial converse to this statement is that if a functor preserves limits/colimits, then its adjoint functor is, if it exists, objectwise given by a limit/colimit over a comma category under/over the given functor (Prop. 27 below). Since these comma categories are in general not small, this involves set-theoretic size subtleties that are dealt with by the adjoint functor theorem (Remark 10 below). We discuss in detail a very special but also very useful special case of this in Prop. 33, further below.

\,

Definition

(limit and colimit)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 4), and let 𝒟\mathcal{D} be any category (Def. 1). In this case one also says that a functor

F:𝒞⟶𝒟 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

is a diagram of shape 𝒞\mathcal{C} in 𝒟\mathcal{D}.

Recalling the functor category (Example 14) [𝒞,𝒟][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}], there is the constant diagram-functor

const:𝒟⟶[𝒞,𝒟] const \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}]

which sends an object X∈𝒟X \in \mathcal{D} to the functor that sends every c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} to XX, and every morphism in 𝒞\mathcal{C} to the identity morphism on XX. Accordingly, every morphism in 𝒟\mathcal{D} is sent by constconst to the natural transformation (Def. 10) all whose components are equal to that morphism.

Now:

  1. if constconst has a right adjoint (Def. 11), this is called the construction of forming the limiting cone of 𝒞\mathcal{C}-shaped diagrams in 𝒟\mathcal{D}, or just limit (or inverse limit) for short, and denoted

    lim⟵𝒞:[𝒞,𝒟]⟶𝒟 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

  2. if constconst has a left adjoint (Def. 11), this is called the construction of forming the colimiting cocone of 𝒞\mathcal{C}-shaped diagrams in 𝒟\mathcal{D}, or just colimit (or direct limit) for short, and denoted

    lim⟶𝒞:[𝒞,𝒟]⟶𝒟 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}
(46)[𝒞,𝒟]⟶AAlim⟶𝒞AA ⟵AAconstAA ⟶AAlim⟵𝒞AA𝒟. [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \array{ \overset{ \phantom{AA}\underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} const \phantom{AA} }{ \longleftarrow } \\ \overset{ \phantom{AA} \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} } \mathcal{D} \,.

If lim⟵𝒞\underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} (lim⟶𝒞\underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim}) exists for a given 𝒟\mathcal{D}, one says that 𝒟\mathcal{D} has all limits (_has all colimits_) of shape 𝒞\mathcal{C}_ or that all limits (colimits) of shape 𝒟\mathcal{D} exist in 𝒟\mathcal{D}. If this is the case for all small diagrams 𝒞\mathcal{C}, one says that 𝒟\mathcal{D} has all limits (_has all colimits_) or that all limits exist in 𝒟\mathcal{D}, (_all colimits exist in 𝒟\mathcal{D}.)

Remark

(limit cones)

Unwinding Definition 39 of limits and colimits, it says the following.

First of all, for d∈𝒟d \in \mathcal{D} any object and F:𝒞⟶𝒟F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} any functor, a natural transformation (Def. 10) of the form

(47)const d⇒iF const_d \overset{i}{\Rightarrow} F

has component morphisms

d ↓ i c F(c) \array{ d \\ \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{i_c}} \\ F(c) }

in 𝒟\mathcal{D}, for each c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C}, and the naturality condition (4) says that these form a commuting diagram (Def. 2) of the form

(48) d i c 1↙ ↘ i c 2 F(c 1) ⟶AAF(f)AA F(c 2) \array{ && d \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ i_{c_1} } }\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{ i_{c_2} }} \\ F(c_1) && \underset{ \phantom{AA} F(f) \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} && F(c_2) }

for each morphism c 1→fc 2c_1 \overset{f}{\to} c_2 in 𝒞\mathcal{C}. Due to the look of this diagram, one also calls such a natural transformation a cone over the functor FF.

Now the counit (Def. 12) of the (const⊣lim⟵)(const \dashv \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim})-adjunction (46) is a natural transformation of the form

(49)const lim⟵F⟶AAϵ FAAF const_{\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} F} \overset{ \phantom{AA} \epsilon_{F} \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} F

and hence is, in components, a cone (48) over FF:

(50) lim⟵F ϵ F(c 1)↙ ↘ ϵ F(c 2) F(c 1) ⟶AAF(f)AA F(c 2) \array{ && \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} F \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ \epsilon_F(c_1) } }\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{ \epsilon_F(c_2) }} \\ F(c_1) && \underset{ \phantom{AA} F(f) \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} && F(c_2) }

to be called the limiting cone over FF

But the universal property of adjunctions says that this is a very special cone: By Prop. 6 the defining property of the limit is equivalently that for every natural transformation of the form (47), hence for every cone of the form (48), there is a unique natural transformation

const d ⇒i˜ const lim⟵ \array{ const_d &\overset{\widetilde i}{\Rightarrow}& const_{ \underset{ \longleftarrow }{\lim} } }

which, due to constancy of the two functors applied in the naturality condition (4), has a constant component morphism

(51)d⟶i˜lim⟵F d \overset{ \widetilde i }{\longrightarrow} \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} F

such that

const d ⟶i˜ const lim⟵F ϵ F↘ ↙ i F \array{ const_d && \overset{\widetilde i}{\longrightarrow} && const_{ \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} F } \\ & {}_{\mathllap{ \epsilon_F }} \searrow && \swarrow_{ \mathrlap{i} } \\ && F }

hence such that (51) factors the given cone (48) through the special cone (50):

d i c 1↙ ↘ i c 2 F(c 1) ⟶AAF(f)AAF(c 2)AAA=AAA d ↓ i˜ lim⟵F ϵ F(c 1)↙ ↘ ϵ F(c 2) F(c 1) ⟶AAF(f)AAF(c 2) \array{ && d \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ i_{c_1} } }\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{ i_{c_2} }} \\ F(c_1) && \underset{ \phantom{AA} F(f) \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} F(c_2) } \phantom{AAA} = \phantom{AAA} \array{ && d \\ && \big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ \widetilde i } } \\ && \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} F \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ \epsilon_F(c_1) } }\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{ \epsilon_F(c_2) }} \\ F(c_1) && \underset{ \phantom{AA} F(f) \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} F(c_2) }

In this case one also says that i˜\widetilde i is a morphism of cones.

Hence a limit cone is a cone over FF, such that every other cone factors through it in a unique way.

Of course this concept of (co)limiting cone over a functor F:𝒞→𝒟F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D} makes sense also when

  1. 𝒞\mathcal{C} is not small,

  2. and/or when a (co-)limiting cone exists only for some but not for all functors of this form.

Example

(terminal/initial object is empty limit/colimit)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category, and let *∈𝒞\ast \in \mathcal{C} be an object. The following are equivalent:

  1. *\ast is a terminal object of 𝒞\mathcal{C} (Def. 3);

  2. *\ast is the limit of the empty diagram.

And formally dual (example 6): Let ∅∈𝒞\emptyset \in \mathcal{C} be an object. The following are equivalent:

  1. ∅\emptyset is an initial object of 𝒞\mathcal{C} (Def. 3);

  2. ∅\emptyset is the colimit of the empty diagram.

Proof

We discuss the case of the terminal object, the other case is formally dual (Example 6).

It suffices to observe that a cone over the empty diagram (Remark 8) is clearly just a plain object of 𝒞\mathcal{C}. Hence a morphism of such cones is just a plain morphism of 𝒞\mathcal{C}. This way the condition on a limiting cone is now manifestly the same as the condition on a terminal object.

Example

(initial object is limit over identity functor)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category, and let ∅∈𝒞\emptyset \in \mathcal{C} be an object. The following are equivalent:

  1. ∅\emptyset is an initial object of 𝒞\mathcal{C} (Def. 3);

  2. ∅\emptyset is the tip of a limit cone (Remark 8) over the identity functor on 𝒞\mathcal{C}.

Proof

First let ∅\emptyset be an initial object. Then, by definition, it is the tip of a unique cone over the identity functor

(52)const ∅ AA ∅ i ∅⇓ i c 1 ∅↙ ↘ i c 2 ∅ id 𝒞 c 1 ⟶f c 2 \array{ const_{\emptyset}&\phantom{AA}& && \emptyset \\ {}^{\mathllap{i^{\emptyset}}}\Downarrow && & {}^{\mathllap{i^{\emptyset}_{c_1}}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{i^{\emptyset}_{c_2}}} \\ id_{\mathcal{C}} && c_1 && \underset{f}{\longrightarrow} && c_2 }

We need to show that that every other cone i xi^x

const x AA x i x⇓ i c 1 x↙ ↘ i c 2 x id 𝒞 c 1 ⟶f c 2 \array{ const_{x}&\phantom{AA}& && x \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mathllap{i^x}}}\Downarrow && & {}^{i^x_{c_1}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{i^x_{c_2}}} \\ id_{\mathcal{C}} && c_1 && \underset{f}{\longrightarrow} && c_2 }

factors uniquely through i ∅i^\emptyset.

First of all, since the cones are over the identity functor, there is the component i ∅ x:x→∅i^x_{\emptyset} \;\colon\; x \to \emptyset, and it is a morphism of cones.

To see that this is the unique morphism of cones, consider any morphism of cones j ∅ xj^x_\emptyset, hence a morphism in 𝒞\mathcal{C} such that i c x=i c ∅∘j ∅ xi^x_c = i^\emptyset_c \circ j^x_\emptyset for all c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C}. Taking here c=∅c = \emptyset yields

i ∅ x =i ∅ ∅⏟=id ∅∘j ∅ x =j ∅ x, \begin{aligned} i^x_\emptyset & = \underset{ = id_\emptyset }{\underbrace{i^\emptyset_{\emptyset}}} \circ j^x_{\emptyset} \\ & = j^x_\emptyset \,, \end{aligned}

where under the brace we used that ∅\emptyset is initial. This proves that i ∅i^\emptyset is the limiting cone.

For the converse, assume now that i ∅i^\emptyset is a limiting cone over the identity functor, with labels as in (52). We need to show that its tip ∅\emptyset is an initial object.

Now the cone condition applied for any object x∈𝒞x \in \mathcal{C} over the morphims f≔i x ∅f \coloneqq i^\emptyset_x says that

i x ∅∘i ∅ ∅=i x ∅ i^{\emptyset}_x \circ i^\emptyset_\emptyset = i^\emptyset_x

which means that i ∅ ∅i^\emptyset_\emptyset constitutes a morphism of cones from i ∅i^\emptyset to itself. But since i ∅i^\emptyset is assumed to be a limiting cone, and since the identity morphism on ∅\emptyset is of course also a morphism of cones from i ∅i^\emptyset to itsely, we deduce that

(53)i ∅ ∅=id ∅. i^\emptyset_\emptyset \;=\; id_{\emptyset} \,.

Now consider any morphism of the form ∅→fx\emptyset \overset{f}{\to} x. Since we already have the morphism ∅→i x ∅x\emptyset \overset{i^\emptyset_x}{\to} x, to show initiality of ∅\emptyset we need to show that f=i x ∅f = i^\emptyset_x.

Indeed, the cone condition of i x ∅i^\emptyset_x applied to ff now yields

i x ∅ =f∘i ∅ ∅⏟=id ∅ =f, \begin{aligned} i^\emptyset_x & = f \circ \underset{ = id_{\emptyset} }{\underbrace{i^\emptyset_\emptyset}} \\ & = f\,, \end{aligned}

where under the brace we used (53).

Example

(limits of presheaves are computed objectwise)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category and write [𝒞 op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] for its category of presheaves (Example 15). Let moreover 𝒟\mathcal{D} be a small category and consider any functor

F:𝒟⟶[𝒞 op,𝒟], F \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}^{op}, \mathcal{D}] \,,

hence a 𝒟\mathcal{D}-shaped diagram in the category of presheaves.

Then

  1. The limit (Def. 39) of FF exists, and is the presheaf which over any object c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} is given by the limit in Set of the values of the presheaves at cc:

    (lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d))(c)≃lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c) \left( \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} F(d) \right)(c) \;\simeq\; \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} F(d)(c)

  2. The colimit (Def. 39) of FF exists, and is the presheaf which over any object c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} is given by the colimit in Set of the values of the presheaves at cc:

    (lim⟶d∈𝒟F(d))(c)≃lim⟶d∈𝒟F(d)(c) \left( \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} F(d) \right)(c) \;\simeq\; \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} F(d)(c)
Proof

We discuss the case of limits, the other case is formally dual (Example 6).

Observe that there is a canonical equivalence (Def. 15)

[𝒟,[𝒞 op,Set]]≃[𝒟×𝒞 op,Set] [\mathcal{D}, [\mathcal{C}^{op}, \Set]] \simeq [\mathcal{D} \times \mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]

where 𝒟×𝒞 op\mathcal{D} \times \mathcal{C}^{op} is the product category.

This makes manifest that a functor F:𝒟→[𝒞 op,Set]F \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] is equivalently a diagram of the form

⋮ ⋮ ↓ ↓ ⋯ ⟶ F(d 1)(c 2) ⟶AA F(d 2)(c 2) ⟶ ⋯ ↓ ↓ ⋯ ⟶ F(d 1)(c 1) ⟶AA F(d 2)(c 1) ⟶ ⋯ ↓ ↓ ⋮ ⋮ \array{ && \vdots && && \vdots \\ && \big\downarrow && && \big\downarrow \\ \cdots &\longrightarrow& F(d_1)(c_2) && \overset{\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} && F(d_2)(c_2) &\longrightarrow& \cdots \\ && \big\downarrow && && \big\downarrow \\ \cdots &\longrightarrow& F(d_1)(c_1) && \overset{\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} && F(d_2)(c_1) &\longrightarrow& \cdots \\ && \big\downarrow && && \big\downarrow \\ && \vdots && && \vdots }

Then observe that taking the limit of each “horizontal row” in such a diagram indead does yield a presheaf on 𝒞\mathcal{C}, in that the construction extends from objects to morphisms, and uniquely so: This is because for any morphism c 1→gc 2c_1 \overset{g}{\to} c_2 in 𝒞\mathcal{C}, a cone over F(−)(c 2)F(-)(c_2) (Remark 8) induces a cone over F(−)(c 1)F(-)(c_1), by vertical composition with F(−)(g)F(-)(g)

lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c 2) ↙ ↘ F(d 1)(c 2) ⟶AA F(d 2)(c 2) F(d 1)(g)↓ ↓ F(d 2)(g) F(d 1)(c 1) ⟶AA F(d 2)(c 1) \array{ && \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c_2) \\ & {}^{ }\swarrow && \searrow \\ F(d_1)(c_2) && \overset{\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} && F(d_2)(c_2) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(d_1)(g)}}\big\downarrow && && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(d_2)(g)}} \\ F(d_1)(c_1) && \overset{\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} && F(d_2)(c_1) }

From this, the universal property of limits of sets (as in Remark 8) implies that there is a unique morphism between the pointwise limits which constitutes a presheaf over 𝒞\mathcal{C}

lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c 2) ↓ lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(g) lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c 1) \array{ \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c_2) \\ \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{ \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(g) }} \\ \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c_1) }

and that is the tip of a cone over the diagram F(−)F(-) in presheaves.

Hence it remains to see that this cone of presheaves is indeed universal.

Now if II is any other cone over FF in the category of presheaves, then by the universal property of the pointswise limits, there is for each c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} a unique morphism of cones in sets

I(c)⟶lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c). I(c) \longrightarrow \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c) \,.

Hence there is at most one morphisms of cones of presheaves, namely if these components make all their naturality squares commute.

I(c 2) ⟶ lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c 2) ↓ ↓ I(c 1) ⟶ lim⟵d∈𝒟F(d)(c 1). \array{ I(c_2) &\longrightarrow& \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c_2) \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ I(c_1) &\longrightarrow& \underset{\underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\longleftarrow}}{lim} F(d)(c_1) } \,.

But since everything else commutes, the two ways of going around this diagram constitute two morphisms from a cone over F(−)(c 1)F(-)(c_1) to the limit cone over F(−)(c 1)F(-)(c_1), and hence they must be equal, by the universal property of limits.

Proposition

(hom-functor preserves limits)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category and write

Hom 𝒞:𝒞 op×𝒞⟶Set Hom_{\mathcal{C}} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Set

for its hom-functor. This preserves limits (Def. 39) in both its arguments (recalling that a limit in the opposite category 𝒞 op\mathcal{C}^{op} is a colimit in 𝒞\mathcal{C}).

More in detail, let X •:ℐ⟶𝒞X_\bullet \colon \mathcal{I} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C} be a diagram. Then:

  1. If the limit lim⟵ iX i\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i X_i exists in 𝒞\mathcal{C} then for all Y∈𝒞Y \in \mathcal{C} there is a natural isomorphism

    Hom 𝒞(Y,lim⟵ iX i)≃lim⟵ i(Hom 𝒞(Y,X i)), Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left(Y, \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i X_i \right) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left( Y, X_i \right) \right) \,,

    where on the right we have the limit over the diagram of hom-sets given by

    Hom 𝒞(Y,−)∘X:ℐ⟶X𝒞⟶Hom 𝒞(Y,−)Set. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,-) \circ X \;\colon\; \mathcal{I} \overset{X}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,-) }{\longrightarrow} Set\,.

  2. If the colimit lim⟶ iX i\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i exists in 𝒞\mathcal{C} then for all Y∈𝒞Y \in \mathcal{C} there is a natural isomorphism

    Hom 𝒞(lim⟶ iX i,Y)≃lim⟵ i(Hom 𝒞(X i,Y)), Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left(\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i ,Y\right) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left( X_i , Y\right) \right) \,,

    where on the right we have the limit over the diagram of hom-sets given by

    Hom 𝒞(−,Y)∘X:ℐ op⟶X𝒞 op⟶Hom 𝒞(−,Y)Set. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,Y) \circ X \;\colon\; \mathcal{I}^{op} \overset{X}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}^{op} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,Y) }{\longrightarrow} Set\,.
Proof

We give the proof of the first statement, the proof of the second statement is formally dual (Example 6).

First observe that, by the very definition of limiting cones, maps out of some YY into them are in natural bijection with the set Cones(Y,X •)Cones\left(Y, X_\bullet \right) of cones over the diagram X •X_\bullet with tip YY:

Hom(Y,lim⟵ iX i)≃Cones(Y,X •). Hom\left( Y, \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i} X_i \right) \;\simeq\; Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet \right) \,.

Hence it remains to show that there is also a natural bijection like so:

Cones(Y,X •)≃lim⟵ i(Hom(Y,X i)). Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet \right) \;\simeq\; \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i} \left( Hom(Y,X_i) \right) \,.

Now, again by the very definition of limiting cones, a single element in the limit on the right is equivalently a cone of the form

{ * const p i↙ ↘ const p j Hom(Y,X i) ⟶X α∘(−) Hom(Y,X j)} i,j∈Obj(ℐ),α∈Hom ℐ(i,j). \left\{ \array{ && \ast \\ & {}^{\mathllap{const_{p_i}}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{const_{p_j}}} \\ Hom(Y,X_i) && \underset{X_\alpha \circ (-)}{\longrightarrow} && Hom(Y,X_j) } \right\}_{i, j \in Obj(\mathcal{I}), \alpha \in Hom_{\mathcal{I}}(i,j) } \,.

This is equivalently for each object i∈ℐi \in \mathcal{I} a choice of morphism p i:Y→X ip_i \colon Y \to X_i , such that for each pair of objects i,j∈ℐi,j \in \mathcal{I} and each α∈Hom ℐ(i,j)\alpha \in Hom_{\mathcal{I}}(i,j) we have X α∘p i=p jX_\alpha \circ p_i = p_j. And indeed, this is precisely the characterization of an element in the set Cones(Y,X •}) Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet\} \right).

Example

(initial and terminal object in terms of adjunction)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1).

  1. The following are equivalent:

    1. 𝒞\mathcal{C} has a terminal object (Def. 3);

    2. the unique functor 𝒞→*\mathcal{C} \to \ast (Def. 7) to the terminal category (Example 3) has a right adjoint (Def. 11)

      *⊥⟶⟵𝒞 \ast \underoverset {\underset{}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}

    Under this equivalence, the terminal object is identified with the image under the right adjoint of the unique object of the terminal category.

  2. Dually, the following are equivalent:

    1. 𝒞\mathcal{C} has an initial object (Def. 3);

    2. the unique functor 𝒞→*\mathcal{C} \to \ast to the terminal category has a left adjoint

      𝒞⊥⟶⟵* \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \ast

    Under this equivalence, the initial object is identified with the image under the left adjoint of the unique object of the terminal category.

Proof

Since the unique hom-set in the terminal category is the singleton, the hom-isomorphism (10) characterizing the adjoint functors is directly the universal property of an initial object in 𝒞\mathcal{C}

Hom 𝒞(L(*),X)≃Hom *(*,R(X))=* Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( L(\ast) , X ) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\ast}( \ast, R(X) ) = \ast

or of a terminal object

Hom 𝒞(X,R(*))≃Hom *(L(X),*)=*, Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( X , R(\ast) ) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\ast}( L(X), \ast ) = \ast \,,

respectively.

Proposition

(left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits)

Let (L⊣R):𝒟→𝒞(L \dashv R) \colon \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} be a pair of adjoint functors (Def. 11). Then

  • LL preserves all colimits (Def. 39) that exist in 𝒞\mathcal{C},

  • RR preserves all limits (Def. 39) in 𝒟\mathcal{D}.

Proof

Let y:I→𝒟y : I \to \mathcal{D} be a diagram whose limit lim ← iy i\lim_{\leftarrow_i} y_i exists. Then we have a sequence of natural isomorphisms, natural in x∈Cx \in C

Hom 𝒞(x,Rlim ← iy i) ≃Hom 𝒟(Lx,lim ← iy i) ≃lim ← iHom 𝒟(Lx,y i) ≃lim ← iHom 𝒞(x,Ry i) ≃Hom 𝒞(x,lim ← iRy i), \begin{aligned} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x, R {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i) & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L x, {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i) \\ & \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L x, y_i) \\ & \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( x, R y_i) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( x, {\lim_\leftarrow}_i R y_i) \,, \end{aligned}

where we used the hom-isomorphism (10) and the fact that any hom-functor preserves limits (Def. 24). Because this is natural in xx the Yoneda lemma implies that we have an isomorphism

Rlim ← iy i≃lim ← iRy i. R {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i R y_i \,.

The argument that shows the preservation of colimits by LL is analogous.

Proposition

(limits commute with limits)

Let 𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′\mathcal{D}' be small categories (Def. 4) and let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1) which admits limits (Def. 39) of shape 𝒟\mathcal{D} as well as limits of shape 𝒟′\mathcal{D}'. Then these limits “commute” with each other, in that for F:𝒟×𝒟′→𝒞F \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \times {\mathcal{D}'} \to \mathcal{C} a functor (hence a diagram of shape the product category), with corresponding adjunct functors (via Example 27)

𝒟′⟶F 𝒟[𝒟,𝒞]AAA𝒟⟶F 𝒟′[𝒟′,𝒞] {\mathcal{D}'} \overset{F_{\mathcal{D}}}{\longrightarrow} [\mathcal{D},\mathcal{C}] \phantom{AAA} {\mathcal{D}} \overset{F_{\mathcal{D}'}}{\longrightarrow} [{\mathcal{D}'}, \mathcal{C}]

we have that the canonical comparison morphism

(54)limF≃lim 𝒟(lim 𝒟′F 𝒟)≃lim 𝒟′(lim 𝒟F 𝒟′) lim F \simeq lim_{\mathcal{D}} (lim_{\mathcal{D}'} F_{\mathcal{D}} ) \simeq lim_{\mathcal{D}'} (lim_{\mathcal{D}} F_{\mathcal{D}'} )

is an isomorphism.

Proof

Since the limit-construction is the right adjoint functor to the constant diagram-functor, this is a special case of right adjoints preserve limits (Prop. 25).

See limits and colimits by example for what formula (54) says for instance for the special case 𝒞=\mathcal{C} = Set.

Remark

(general non-commutativity of limits with colimits)

In general limits do not commute with colimits. But under a number of special conditions of interest they do. Special cases and concrete examples are discussed at commutativity of limits and colimits.

\,

Proposition

(pointwise expression of left adjoints in terms of limits over comma categories)

A functor R:𝒞⟶𝒟R \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} (Def. 7) has a left adjoint L:𝒟⟶𝒞L \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C} (Def. 11) precisely if

  1. RR preserves all limits (Def. 39) that exist in 𝒞\mathcal{C};

  2. for each object d∈𝒟d \in \mathcal{D}, the limit (Def. 39) of the canonical functor (22) out of the comma category (Example 20)

    d/R⟶𝒞 d/R \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

    exists.

In this case the value of the left adjoint LL on dd is given by that limit:

(55)L(d)≃lim⟵(c,d ↓ f R(c))∈d/Rc L(d) \;\simeq\; \underset{\underset{ \left( c, \array{ d \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(c) } \right) \in d/R }{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} c
Proof

First assume that the left adjoint exist. Then

  1. RR is a right adjoint and hence preserves limits since all right adjoints preserve limits (Prop. 25);

  2. by Prop. 6 the adjunction unit provides a universal morphism η d\eta_d into L(d)L(d), and hence, by Prop. 7, exhibits (L(d),η d)(L(d), \eta_d) as the initial object of the comma category d/Rd/R. The limit over any category with an initial object exists, as it is given by that initial object.

Conversely, assume that the two conditions are satisfied and let L(d)L(d) be given by (55). We need to show that this yields a left adjoint.

By the assumption that RR preserves all limits that exist, we have

(56)R(L(d)) =R(lim⟵(c,d ↓ f R(c))∈d/Rc) ≃lim⟵(c,d ↓ f R(c))∈d/RR(c) \array{ R(L(d)) & = R\left( \underset{\underset{ \left( c, \array{ d \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(c) } \right) \in d/R }{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} c \right) \\ & \simeq \underset{\underset{ \left( c, \array{ d \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(c) } \right) \in d/R }{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} R(c) }

Since the d→fR(d)d \overset{f}{\to} R(d) constitute a cone over the diagram of the R(d)R(d), there is universal morphism

d⟶AAη dAAR(L(d)). d \overset{\phantom{AA} \eta_d \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \,.

By Prop. 6 it is now sufficient to show that η d\eta_d is a universal morphism into L(d)L(d), hence that for all c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C} and d⟶gR(c)d \overset{g}{\longrightarrow} R(c) there is a unique morphism L(d)⟶f˜cL(d) \overset{\widetilde f}{\longrightarrow} c such that

d η d↙ ↘ f R(L(d)) ⟶AAR(f˜)AA R(c) L(d) ⟶AAf˜AA c \array{ && d \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ \eta_d }}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(L(d)) && \underset{\phantom{AA}R(\widetilde f)\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} && R(c) \\ L(d) &&\underset{\phantom{AA}\widetilde f\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}&& c }

By Prop. 7, this is equivalent to (L(d),η d)(L(d), \eta_d) being the initial object in the comma category c/Rc/R, which in turn is equivalent to it being the limit of the identity functor on c/Rc/R (by Example 23). But this follows directly from the limit formulas (55) and (56).

Remark

(adjoint functor theorem)

Beware the subtle point in Prop. 27, that the comma category c/Fc/F is in general not a small category (Def. 4): It has typically “as many” objects as 𝒞\mathcal{C} has, and 𝒞\mathcal{C} is not assumed to be small (while of course it may happen to be). But typical categories, such as notably the category of sets (Example 1) are generally guaranteed only to admit limits over small categories. For this reason, Prop. 27 is rarely useful for finding an adjoint functor which is not already established to exist by other means.

But there are good sufficient conditions known, on top of the condition that RR preserves limits, which guarantee the existence of an adjoint functor, after all. This is the topic of the adjoint functor theorem (one of the rare instances of useful and non-trivial theorems in mathematics for which issues of set theoretic size play a crucial role for their statement and proof).

A very special but also very useful case of the adjoint functor theorem is the existence of adjoints of base change functors between categories of (enriched) presheaves via Kan extension. This we discuss as Prop. 33 below. Since this is most conveniently phrased in terms of special limits/colimits called ends/coends (Def. 40 below) we first discuss these.

\,

Ends and coends

For working with enriched categories (Def. 32) , a certain shape of limits/colimits (Def. 39) is particularly relevant: these are called ends and coends (Def. 40 below). We here introduce these and then derive some of their basic properties, such as notably the expression for Kan extension in terms of (co-)ends (prop. 33 below).

\,

Definition

((co)end)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32). Let

F:𝒞 op×𝒞⟶𝒱 F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

be an enriched functor (Def. 34) out of the enriched product category of 𝒞\mathcal{C} with its opposite category (Def. 33). Then:

  1. The coend of FF, denoted

    ∫c∈𝒞F(c,c)∈𝒱, \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \;\in\; \mathcal{V} \,,

    is the coequalizer in 𝒱\mathcal{V} of the two actions encoded in FF via Example 37:

    ∐c,d∈𝒞𝒞(c,d)⊗F(d,c)AAAAAAAA⟶⊔c,dρ (d,c)(c)⟶⊔c,dρ (c,d)(d)∐c∈𝒞F(c,c)⟶coeq∫c∈𝒞F(c,c). \underset{c,d \in \mathcal{C}}{\coprod} \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(d,c) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \rho_{(d,c)}(c) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \rho_{(c,d)}(d) }{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\coprod} F(c,c) \overset{coeq}{\longrightarrow} \overset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \,.

  2. The end of FF, denoted

    ∫c∈𝒞F(c,c)∈𝒱, \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \;\in\; \mathcal{V} \,,

    is the equalizer in 𝒱\mathcal{V} of the adjuncts of the two actions encoded in FF via example 37:

    ∫c∈𝒞F(c,c)⟶equ∏c∈𝒞F(c,c)AAAAAAAA⟶⊔c,dρ˜ (c,d)(c)⟶⊔c,dρ˜ d,c(d)∏c∈𝒞[𝒞(c,d),F(c,d)]. \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \overset{\;\;equ\;\;}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} F(c,c) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \tilde \rho_{(c,d)}(c) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \tilde\rho_{d,c}(d)}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} \big[ \mathcal{C}\left(c,d\right), \; F\left(c,d\right) \big] \,.
Example

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos, let G∈𝒱G \in \mathcal{V} be a group object. There is the n the one-object 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category BG\mathbf{B}G as in Example 5.

Then a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor

(X,ρ l):BG⟶𝒱 (X,\rho_l) \;\colon\; \mathbf{B}G \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is an object X≔F(*)∈𝒱X \coloneqq F(\ast) \; \in \mathcal{V} equipped with a morphism

ρ l:G⊗X⟶X \rho_l \;\colon\; G \otimes X \longrightarrow X

satisfying the action property. Hence this is equivalently an action of GG on XX.

The opposite category (def. 33) (BG) op(\mathbf{B}G)^{op} comes from the opposite group-object

(BG) op=B(G op). (\mathbf{B}G)^{op} = \mathbf{B}(G^{op}) \,.

(The isomorphism G≃G opG \simeq G^{op} induces a canonical euqivalence of enriched categories (BG) op≃BG(\mathbf{B}G)^{op} \simeq \mathbf{B}G.)

So an enriched functor

(Y,ρ r):(BG) op⟶𝒱 (Y,\rho_r) \;\colon\; (\mathbf{B} G)^{op} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is equivalently a right action of GG.

Therefore the coend of two such functors (def. 40) coequalizes the relation

(xg,y)∼(x,gy) (x g,\;y) \sim (x,\; g y)

(where juxtaposition denotes left/right action) and is the quotient of the plain tensor product by the diagonal action of the group GG:

∫*∈B(G +)(Y,ρ r)(*)⊗(X,ρ l)(*)≃Y⊗ GX. \overset{\ast \in \mathbf{B}(G_+)}{\int} (Y,\rho_r)(\ast) \,\otimes\, (X,\rho_l)(\ast) \;\simeq\; Y \otimes_G X \,.
Example

(enriched natural transformations as ends)

Let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small enriched category (Def. 32). For F,G:𝒞⟶𝒱 F, G \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V} two enriched presheaves (Example 36), the end (def. 40) of the internal-hom-functor

[F(−),G(−)]:𝒞 op×𝒞⟶𝒱 [F(-),G(-)] \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is an object of 𝒱\mathcal{V} whose underlying set (Example 30) is the set of enriched natural transformations F⇒GF \Rightarrow G (Def. 35)

Hom 𝒱(1,(∫c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)]))≃Hom [𝒞,𝒱](F,G). Hom_{\mathcal{V}}\left(1, \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \big[ F(c),G(c) \big] \right) \right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{[\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]}(F,G) \,.
Proof

The underlying pointed set functor Hom 𝒱(1,−):𝒱→SetHom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-)\colon \mathcal{V}\to Set preserves all limits, since hom-functors preserve limits? (Prop. 24). Therefore there is an equalizer diagram in Set of the form

Hom 𝒱(1,(∫c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)]))⟶equ∏c∈𝒞Hom 𝒱(F(c),G(c))AAAAAAAA⟶⊔c,dU(ρ˜ (c,d)(c))⟶⊔c,dU(ρ˜ d,c(d))∏c,d∈𝒞Hom 𝒱(𝒞(c,d),[F(c),G(d)]), Hom_{\mathcal{V}}\left(1, \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \right) \overset{equ}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(F(c),G(c)) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} U(\tilde \rho_{(c,d)}(c)) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} U(\tilde\rho_{d,c}(d))}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c,d\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} Hom_{\mathcal{V}}( \mathcal{C}(c,d), [F(c),G(d)] ) \,,

where we used Example 31 to identify underlying sets of internal homs with hom-sets.

Here the object in the middle is just the set of indexed sets of component morphisms {F(c)→η cG(c)} c∈𝒞\left\{ F(c)\overset{\eta_c}{\to} G(c)\right\}_{c\in \mathcal{C}}. The two parallel maps in the equalizer diagram take such a collection to the indexed set of composites (43) and (44). Hence that these two are equalized is precisely the condition that the indexed set of components constitutes an enriched natural transformation.

Conversely, example 43 says that ends over bifunctors of the form [F(−),G(−))][F(-),G(-))] constitute hom-spaces between pointed topologically enriched functors:

Definition

(enriched presheaf category)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32).

Then the 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaf category [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] is 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor category from 𝒞\mathcal{C} to 𝒱\mathcal{V}, hence is the following 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32)

  1. the objects are the 𝒞\mathcal{C}-enriched functors 𝒞→F𝒱\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\to}\mathcal{V} (Def. 34);

  2. the hom-objects are the ends

    (57)[𝒞,𝒱](F,G)≔∫ c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](F,G) \;\coloneqq\; \int_{c\in \mathcal{C}} [F(c),G(c)]

  3. the composition operation on these is defined to be the one induced by the composite maps

    (∫c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)])⊗(∫c∈𝒞[G(c),H(c)])⟶∏c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)]⊗[G(c),H(c)]⟶(∘ F(c),G(c),H(c)) c∈𝒞∏c∈𝒞[F(c),H(c)], \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \otimes \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [G(c),H(c)] \right) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} [F(c),G(c)] \otimes [G(c),H(c)] \overset{(\circ_{F(c),G(c),H(c)})_{c\in \mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} [F(c),H(c)] \,,

    where the first morphism is degreewise given by projection out of the limits that defined the ends. This composite evidently equalizes the two relevant adjunct actions (as in the proof of example 43) and hence defines a map into the end

    (∫c∈𝒞[F(c),G(c)])⊗(∫c∈𝒞[G(c),H(c)])⟶∫c∈𝒞[F(c),H(c)]. \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \otimes \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [G(c),H(c)] \right) \longrightarrow \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),H(c)] \,.

By Example 43, the underlying plain category (Example 33) of this enriched functor category is the plain functor category of enriched functors from Example 38.

Proposition

(enriched Yoneda lemma)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31) let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small enriched category (Def. 32). For F:𝒞→𝒱F \colon \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} an enriched presheaf (Example 36) and for c∈𝒞c\in \mathcal{C} an object, there is a natural isomorphism

[𝒞,𝒱](𝒞(c,−),F)≃F(c) [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](\mathcal{C}(c,-),\; F) \;\simeq\; F(c)

between the hom-object of the enriched functor category (Def. 41), from the functor represented by cc to FF, and the value of FF on cc.

In terms of the ends (def. 40) defining these hom-objects (57), this means that

∫d∈𝒞[𝒞(c,d),F(d)]≃F(c). \underset{d\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{C}(c,d), F(d)] \;\simeq\; F(c) \,.

In this form the statement is also known as Yoneda reduction.

Now that natural transformations are expressed in terms of ends (example 43), as is the enriched Yoneda lemma (prop. 28), it is natural to consider the dual statement (Example 6) involving coends:

Proposition

(enriched co-Yoneda lemma)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32). For F:𝒞→𝒱F \colon \mathcal{C}\to \mathcal{V} an enriched presheaf (Def. 36) and for c∈𝒞c\in \mathcal{C} an object, there is a natural isomorphism

F(−)≃∫c∈𝒞𝒞(c,−)⊗F(c). F(-) \simeq \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \,.

Moreover, the morphism that hence exhibits F(c)F(c) as the coequalizer of the two morphisms in def. 40 is componentwise the canonical action

𝒞(c,d)⊗F(c)⟶F(d) \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(c) \longrightarrow F(d)

which is adjunct to the component map 𝒞(d,c)→[F(c),F(d)]\mathcal{C}(d,c) \to [F(c),F(d)] of the enriched functor FF.

(e.g. MMSS 00, lemma 1.6)

Proof

By the definition of coends and the universal property of colimits, enriched natural transformations of the form

(∫c∈𝒞𝒞(c,−)⊗F(c))⟶G \left( \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \right) \longrightarrow G

are in natural bijection with systems of component morphisms

𝒞(c,d)⊗F(c)⟶G(d) \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(c) \longrightarrow G(d)

which satisfy some compatibility conditions in their dependence on cc and dd (natural in dd and “extranatural” in cc). By the internal hom adjunction, these are in natural bijection to systems of morphisms of the form

F(c)⟶[𝒞(c,d),G(d)] F(c) \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}(c,d), G(d)]

satisfying the analogous compatibility conditions. By Example 43 these are in natural bijection with systems of morphisms

F(c)⟶[𝒞,𝒱](𝒞(c,−),G(−)) F(c) \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}](\mathcal{C}(c,-), G(-))

natural in cc

By the enriched Yoneda lemma (Prop. 28), these, finally, are in natural bijection with systems of morphisms

F(c)⟶G(c) F(c) \longrightarrow G(c)

natural in cc. Moreover, all these identifications are also natural in GG. Therefore, in summary, this shows that there is a natural isomorphism

Hom [𝒞,𝒱](∫c∈𝒞𝒞(c,−)⊗F(c),(−))≃Hom [𝒞,𝒱](F,(−)). Hom_{[\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}]} \left( \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \;,\; (-) \right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{[\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}]} \left( F, (-) \right) \,.

With this, the ordinary Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) in the form of the Yoneda embedding of [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] implies the required isomorphism.

Example

(co-Yoneda lemma over Set)

Consider the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 29) in the special case 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set (Example 29).

In this case the coequalizer in question is the set of equivalence classes of pairs

(c→c 0,x)∈𝒞(c,c 0)⊗F(c), ( c \overset{}{\to} c_0,\; x ) \;\; \in \mathcal{C}(c,c_0) \otimes F(c) \,,

where two such pairs

(c→fc 0,x∈F(c)),(d→gc 0,y∈F(d)) ( c \overset{f}{\to} c_0,\; x \in F(c) ) \,,\;\;\;\; ( d \overset{g}{\to} c_0,\; y \in F(d) )

are regarded as equivalent if there exists

c→ϕd c \overset{\phi}{\to} d

such that

f=g∘ϕ,andy=ϕ(x). f = g \circ \phi \,, \;\;\;\;\;and\;\;\;\;\; y = \phi(x) \,.

(Because then the two pairs are the two images of the pair (g,x)(g,x) under the two morphisms being coequalized.)

But now considering the case that d=c 0d = c_0 and g=id c 0g = id_{c_0}, so that f=ϕf = \phi shows that any pair

(c→ϕc 0,x∈F(c)) ( c \overset{\phi}{\to} c_0, \; x \in F(c))

is identified, in the coequalizer, with the pair

(id c 0,ϕ(x)∈F(c 0)), (id_{c_0},\; \phi(x) \in F(c_0)) \,,

hence with ϕ(x)∈F(c 0)\phi(x)\in F(c_0).

As a conceptually important corollary we obtain:

Proposition

(category of presheaves is free co-completion)

For 𝒞\mathcal{C} a small category (Def. 4), its Yoneda embedding 𝒞↪y[𝒞 op,Set]\mathcal{C} \overset{y}{\hookrightarrow} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Prop. 2) exhibits the category of presheaves [𝒞 op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Example 15) as the free co-completion of 𝒞\mathcal{C} under forming colimits (Def. 39), in that it is a universal morphism, as in Def. 13 but “up to natural isomorphism”, into a category with all colimits (by Example 40) in the following sense:

  1. for 𝒟\mathcal{D} any category with all colimits (Def. 39);

  2. for F:𝒞⟶𝒟F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} any functor;

there is a functor F˜:[𝒞 op,Set]⟶𝒟\widetilde F \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}, unique up to natural isomorphism such that

  1. F˜\widetilde F preserves all colimits,

  2. F˜\widetilde F extends FF through the Yoneda embedding, in that the following diagram commutes, up to natural isomorphism (Def. 10):

𝒞 y↙ ⇙ ↘ F [𝒞 op,Set] ⟶F˜ 𝒟 \array{ && \mathcal{C} \\ & {}^{y}\swarrow &\swArrow& \searrow^{\mathrlap{F}} \\ \mathrlap{ \!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\! [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] } && \underset{ \widetilde F }{\longrightarrow} && \mathcal{D} }

Hence when interpreting presheaves as generalized spaces, this says that “generalized spaces are precisely what is obtained from allowing arbitrary gluings of ordinary spaces”, see also Remark 15 below.

Proof

The last condition says that F˜\widetilde F is fixed on representable presheaves by

(58)F˜(y(c))≃F(c). \widetilde F( y(c) ) \simeq F(c) \,.

and in fact naturally so:

(59)c 1 F˜(y(c 1)) ≃ F(c 1) f↓ F(y(f))↓ ↓ F(f) c 2 F˜(y(c 2)) ≃ F(c 2) \array{ c_1&& \widetilde F( y(c_1) ) &\simeq& F(c_1) \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\big\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{ F(y(f)) }}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{ F(f) }} \\ c_2 && \widetilde F (y(c_2)) &\simeq& F(c_2) }

But the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 29) expresses every presheaf X∈[𝒞 op,Set]\mathbf{X} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] as a colimit of representable presheaves (in the special case of enrichment over SetSet, Example 44)

X≃∫ c∈𝒞y(c)⋅X(c). \mathbf{X} \;\simeq\; \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} y(c) \cdot \mathbf{X}(c) \,.

Since F˜\tilde F is required to preserve any colimit and hence these particular colimits, (58) implies that F˜\widetilde F is fixed to act, up to isomorphism, as

F˜(X) =F˜(∫ c∈𝒞y(c)⋅X(c)) ≔∫ c∈𝒞F(c)⋅X(c)∈𝒟 \begin{aligned} \widetilde F(\mathbf{X}) & = \widetilde F \left( \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} y(c) \cdot \mathbf{X}(c) \right) & \coloneqq \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} F(c) \cdot \mathbf{X}(c) \;\;\;\;\in \mathcal{D} \end{aligned}

(where the colimit on the right is computed in 𝒟\mathcal{D}!).

Remark

The statement of the co-Yoneda lemma in prop. 29 is a kind of categorification of the following statement in analysis (whence the notation with the integral signs):

For XX a topological space, f:X→ℝf \colon X \to\mathbb{R} a continuous function and δ(−,x 0)\delta(-,x_0) denoting the Dirac distribution, then

∫ x∈Xδ(x,x 0)f(x)=f(x 0). \int_{x \in X} \delta(x,x_0) f(x) = f(x_0) \,.

It is this analogy that gives the name to the following statement:

Proposition

(Fubini theorem for (co)-ends)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞 1,𝒞 2\mathcal{C}_1, \mathcal{C}_2 be two 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32) and

F:(𝒞 1×𝒞 2) op×(𝒞 1×𝒞 2)⟶𝒱 F \;\colon\; \left( \mathcal{C}_1\times\mathcal{C}_2 \right)^{op} \times (\mathcal{C}_1 \times\mathcal{C}_2) \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34) from the product category with opposite categories (Def. 33), as shown.

Then its end and coend (def. 40) is equivalently formed consecutively over each variable, in either order:

∫(c 1,c 2)F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))≃∫c 1∫c 2F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))≃∫c 2∫c 1F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2)) \overset{(c_1,c_2)}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \overset{c_1}{\int} \overset{c_2}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \overset{c_2}{\int} \overset{c_1}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2))

and

∫(c 1,c 2)F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))≃∫c 1∫c 2F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))≃∫c 2∫c 1F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2)). \underset{(c_1,c_2)}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \underset{c_1}{\int} \underset{c_2}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \underset{c_2}{\int} \underset{c_1}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \,.
Proof

Because limits commute with limits, and colimits commute with colimits.

Remark

(internal hom preserves ends)

Let 𝒱\mathcal{V} be a cosmos (Def. 31). Since the internal hom-functor in 𝒱\mathcal{V} (Def. 29) preserves limits in both variables (Prop. 21), in particular it preserves ends (Def. 40) in the second variable, and sends coends in the second variable to ends:

For all small 𝒞\mathcal{C}-enriched categories, 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functors F:𝒞 op⊗𝒞→𝒱F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \otimes \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} (Def. 34) and all objects X∈𝒱X \in \mathcal{V} we have natural isomorphisms

[X,∫ c∈𝒞F(c,c)]≃∫ c∈𝒞[X,F(c,c)] \left[ X , \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} F(c,c) \right] \;\simeq\; \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ X, F(c,c) \right]

and

[∫ c∈𝒞F(c,c),X]≃∫ c∈𝒞[F(c,c),X]. \left[ \int_{c \in \mathcal{C}} F(c,c) , X \right] \;\simeq\; \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ F(c,c), X \right] \,.

With this coend calculus in hand, there is an elegant proof of the defining universal property of the smash tensoring and powering enriched presheaves (Def. 36):

Proposition

(universal property of tensoring and powering of enriched presheaves)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C} be a small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 32), with [𝒞,𝒱][\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] the corresponding enriched presheaf category.

Then there are natural isomorphisms

[𝒞,𝒱](X⋅K,Y)≃[K,([𝒞,𝒱](X,Y))] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]( X \cdot K ,\, Y ) \;\simeq\; [K,\big( [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X, Y \right) \big)]

and

[𝒞,𝒱](X,Y K)≃[K,([𝒞,𝒞](X,Y))] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X,\, Y^K \right) \;\simeq\; [K, \big( [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C}](X,Y) \big) ]

for all X,Y∈[𝒞,𝒱]X,Y \in [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] and all K∈𝒞K \in \mathcal{C}, where (−) K(-)^K is the powering and (−)⋅K(-)\cdot K the tensoring from Def. 36.

In particular there is the composite natural isomorphism

[𝒞,𝒱](X⋅K,Y)≃[𝒞,𝒱](X,Y K) [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X \cdot K, Y) \;\simeq\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X, Y^K \right)

exhibiting a pair of adjoint functors

[𝒞,𝒱]⊥⟶(−) K⟵(−)⋅K[𝒞,𝒱]. [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{(-)^K}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{(-) \cdot K}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \,.
Proof

Via the end-expression for [𝒞,𝒱](−,−)[\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](-,-) from Example 43, and the fact (remark 12) that the internal hom-functor ends in the second variable, this reduces to the fact that [−,−][-,-] is the internal hom in the closed monoidal category 𝒱\mathcal{V} (Example 34) and hence satisfies the internal tensor/hom-adjunction isomorphism (prop. 20):

[𝒞,𝒱](X⋅K,Y) =∫c[(X⋅K)(c),Y(c)] ≃∫c[X(c)⊗K,Y(x)] ≃∫c[K,[X(c),Y(c)]] ≃[K,∫c[X(c),Y(c)]] =[K,([𝒞,𝒱](X,Y))] \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X \cdot K, Y) & = \underset{c}{\int} [ (X \cdot K)(c), Y(c) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [X(c) \otimes K, Y(x)] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [K,[X(c), Y(c)]] \\ & \simeq [K, \underset{c}{\int} [X(c),Y(c)]] \\ & = [K,\left( [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}](X,Y)\right)] \end{aligned}

and

[𝒞,𝒱](X,Y K) =∫c[X(c),Y K(c)] ≃∫c[X(c),[K,Y(c)]] ≃∫c[X(c)⊗K,Y(c)] ≃∫c[K,[X(c),Y(c)]] ≃[K,∫c[X(c),Y(c)]] ≃[K,[𝒞,𝒱](X,Y]. \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X, Y^K) & = \underset{c}{\int} [X(c), Y^K(c)] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [ X(c), [K,Y(c)] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [ X(c) \otimes K, Y(c) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [K, [X(c),Y(c)]] \\ & \simeq [K, \underset{c}{\int} [X(c),Y(c)] ] \\ & \simeq [K, [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X,Y] \,. \end{aligned}

\,

Kan extensions

Proposition

(Kan extension)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞,𝒟\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32) and let

p:𝒞⟶𝒟 p \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34). Then precomposition with pp constitutes a functor between the corresponding 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaf categories (Def. 41)

(60)p *:[𝒟,𝒱] ⟶ [𝒞,𝒱] G ↦ G∘p p^\ast \;\colon\; \array{ [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] &\longrightarrow& [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \\ G &\mapsto& G \circ p }

  1. This enriched functor p *p^\ast (60) has a enriched left adjoint Lan pLan_p (Def. 37), called left Kan extension along pp

    [𝒟,𝒱]⊥⟶p *⟵Lan p[𝒞,𝒱] [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{p^\ast}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{Lan_p }{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    which is given objectwise by the coend (def. 40):

    (61)(Lan pF):d↦∫c∈𝒞𝒟(p(c),d)⊗F(c). (Lan_p F) \;\colon\; d \;\mapsto \; \overset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) \,.

  2. The enriched functor p *p^\ast (60) has a enriched right adjoint Ran pRan_p (Def. 37), called right Kan extension along pp

    [𝒞,𝒱]⊥⟶Ran p⟵p *[𝒟,𝒱] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{Ran_p}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{p^\ast}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]

    which is given objectwise by the end (def. 40):

    (62)(Ran pF):d↦∫c∈𝒞[𝒟(d,p(c)),F(c)]. (Ran_p F) \;\colon\; d \;\mapsto \; \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{D}(d,p(c)), F(c)] \,.

In summary, this means that the enriched functor

𝒞⟶p𝒟 \mathcal{C} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

induces, via Kan extension, an adjoint triple (Remark 3) of enriched functors

(63)Lan p⊣p *⊣Ran p:[𝒞,𝒱]↔[𝒟,𝒱]. Lan_p \;\dashv\; p^\ast \;\dashv\; Ran_p \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] \leftrightarrow [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] \,.
Proof

Use the expression of enriched natural transformations in terms of [[coends (example 43 and def. 41), then use the respect of [−,−][-,-] for ends/coends (remark 12), use the internal-hom adjunction (36), use the Fubini theorem (prop. 31) and finally use Yoneda reduction (prop. 28) to obtain a sequence of natural isomorphisms as follows:

[𝒟,𝒱](Lan pF,G) =∫d∈𝒟[(Lan pF)(d),G(d)] =∫d∈𝒟[∫c∈𝒞𝒟(p(c),d)⊗F(c),G(d)] ≃∫d∈𝒟∫c∈𝒞[𝒟(p(c),d)⊗F(c),G(d)] ≃∫c∈𝒞∫d∈𝒟[F(c),[𝒟(p(c),d),G(d)]] ≃∫c∈𝒞[F(c),∫d∈𝒟[𝒟(p(c),d),G(d)]] ≃∫c∈𝒞[F(c),G(p(c))] =[𝒞,𝒱](F,p *G). \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]( Lan_p F, \, G ) & = \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ (Lan_p F)(d), \, G(d) ] \\ & = \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) ,\; G(d) \right] \\ &\simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) \,,\; G(d) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [F(c), [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) , \, G(d) ] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c), \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) , \, G(d) ] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [ F(c), G(p(c)) ] \\ & = [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](F,p^\ast G) \end{aligned} \,.

and similarly:

[𝒟,𝒱](G,Ran pF) ≃∫d∈𝒟[G(d),(Ran pF)(d),] ≃∫d∈𝒟[G(d),∫c∈𝒞[𝒟(d,p(c)),F(c)]] ≃∫d∈𝒟∫c∈𝒞[G(d)⊗𝒟(d,p(c)),F(c)] ≃∫c∈𝒞[∫d∈𝒟G(d)⊗𝒟(d,p(c)),F(c)] ≃∫c∈𝒟[G(p(c)),F(c)] ≃[𝒞,𝒱](p *G,F) \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]( G,\, Ran_p F ) & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ G(d) ,\, (Ran_p F)(d), \, ] \\ & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ G(d) ,\, \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{D}(d,p(c)), F(c)] \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \left[ G(d) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \left[ \overset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} G(d) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{c \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ G(p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]( p^\ast G , F ) \end{aligned}
Example

(coend formula for left Kan extension of ordinary presheaves)

Consider the cosmos to be 𝒱=\mathcal{V} = Set, via Example 29, so that small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32) are just a plain small category (Def. 1) by Example 32, and 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaves (Example 36) are just plain presheaves (Example 15).

Then for any plain functor (Def. 7)

𝒞 op⟶AApAA(𝒞′) op \mathcal{C}^{op} \overset{\phantom{AA} p \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} (\mathcal{C}')^{op}

the general formula (61) for left Kan extension

[𝒞 op,Set]⟶Lan p[(𝒞′) op,Set] [\mathcal{C}^{op},Set] \overset{Lan_p}{\longrightarrow} [(\mathcal{C}')^{op}, Set]

is

(Lan pF)(c′)≃∫ c∈CC′(c′,p(c))×F(c). (Lan_p F)(c') \simeq \int^{c \in C} C'(c', p(c)) \times F(c) \,.

Using here the Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) to rewrite F(c)≃Hom PSh(C)(c,F)F(c) \simeq Hom_{PSh(C)}(c,F), this is

(Lan pF)(c′)≃∫ c∈CHom C′(c′,p(c))×Hom PSh(C)(c,F). (Lan_p F)(c') \simeq \int^{c \in C} Hom_{C'}(c', p(c)) \times Hom_{PSh(C)}(c,F) \,.

Hence this coend-set consists of equivalence classes of pairs of morphisms

(c′→p(c),c→F) (c' \to p(c), c \to F)

where two such are regarded as equivalent whenever there is f:c′ 1→c′ 2f \colon c'_1 \to c'_2 such that

c′ ↙ ↘ p(c 1) ⟶p(f) p(c 2) c 1 ⟶f c 2 ↘ ↙ F. \array{ && c' \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ p(c_1) && \stackrel{p(f)}{\longrightarrow} && p(c_2) \\ c_1 && \stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow} && c_2 \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && F } \,.

This is particularly suggestive when pp is a full subcategory inclusion (Def. 9). For in that case we may imagine that a representative pair (c′→p(c),c→F)(c' \to p(c), c \to F) is a stand-in for the actual pullback of elements of FF along the would-be composite “c′→c→Fc'\to c \to F”, only that this composite need not be defined. But the above equivalence relation is precisely that under which this composite would be invariant.

Further properties

We collect here further key properties of the various universal constructions considered above.

\,

Proposition

(left Kan extension preserves representable functors)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let

𝒞⟶p𝒟 \mathcal{C} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34) between small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32).

Then the left Kan extension Lan pLan_p (Prop. 33) takes representable enriched presheaves 𝒞(c,−):𝒞→𝒱\mathcal{C}(c,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} to their image under pp:

Lan p𝒞(c,−)≃𝒟(p(c),−) Lan_p \mathcal{C}(c, -) \;\simeq\; \mathcal{D}(p(c), -)

for all c∈Cc \in C.

Proof

By the coend forumla (61) have naturally in d′∈𝒟d' \in \mathcal{D} the expression

Lan p𝒞(c,−):d′↦ ∫ c′∈C𝒟(p(c′),d′)⊗𝒞(c,−)(c′) ≃∫ c′∈C𝒟(p(c′),d′)⊗𝒞(c,c′) ≃𝒟(p(c),d′), \begin{aligned} Lan_p \mathcal{C}(c,-) \;\colon\; d' \mapsto & \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), d') \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,-)(c') \\ & \simeq \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), d') \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,c') \\ & \simeq \mathcal{D}(p(c), d') \end{aligned} \,,

where the last step is the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 29).

Example

(Kan extension of adjoint pair is adjoint quadruple)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let 𝒞\mathcal{C}, 𝒟\mathcal{D} be two small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32) and let

𝒞⊥⟶p⟵q𝒟 \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{q}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

be a 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched adjunction (Def. 37). Then there are 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphisms (Def. 35)

(q op) *≃Lan p op:[𝒞 op,𝒱]⟶[𝒟 op,𝒱] (q^{op})^\ast \;\simeq\; Lan_{p^{op}} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{D}^{op},\mathcal{V}]
(p op) *≃Ran q op:[𝒟 op,𝒱]⟶[𝒞 op,𝒱] (p^{op})^\ast \;\simeq\; Ran_{q^{op}} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{D}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}]

between the precomposition on enriched presheaves with one functor and the left/right Kan extension of the other (Def. 33).

By essential uniqueness of adjoint functors, this means that the two adjoint triples (Remark 3) given by Kan extension (63) of qq and pp

Lan q op ⊣ (q op) * ⊣ Ran q op Lan p op ⊣ (p op) * ⊣ Ran p op \array{ Lan_{q^{op}} &\dashv& (q^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{q^{op}} \\ && Lan_{p^{op}} &\dashv& (p^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{p^{op}} }

merge into an adjoint quadruple (Remark 3)

Lan q op ⊣ (q op) * ⊣ (p op) * ⊣ Ran p op:[𝒞 op,𝒱]↔[𝒟 op,𝒱] \array{ Lan_{q^{op}} &\dashv& (q^{op})^\ast &\dashv& (p^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{p^{op}} } \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \leftrightarrow [\mathcal{D}^{op}, \mathcal{V}]
Proof

For every enriched presheaf F:𝒞 op→𝒱F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \to \mathcal{V} we have a sequence of 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphism as follows

(Lan p opF)(d) ≃∫ c∈𝒞𝒟(d,p(c))⊗F(c) ≃∫ c∈𝒞𝒞(q(d),c)⊗F(c) ≃F(q(d)) =((q op) *F)(d). \begin{aligned} (Lan_{p^{op}} F)(d) & \simeq \int^{ c \in \mathcal{C} } \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)) \otimes F(c) \\ & \simeq \int^{ c \in \mathcal{C} } \mathcal{C}(q(d),c) \otimes F(c) \\ & \simeq F(q(d)) \\ & = \left( (q^{op})^\ast F\right) (d) \,. \end{aligned}

Here the first step is the coend-formula for left Kan extension (Prop. 33), the second step if the enriched adjunction-isomorphism (45) for q⊣pq \dashv p and the third step is the co-Yoneda lemma.

This shows the first statement, which, by essential uniqueness of adjoints, implies the following statements.

Proposition

(left Kan extension along fully faithful functor is fully faithful)

For 𝒱\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 31), let

𝒞↪AApAA𝒟 \mathcal{C} \overset{\phantom{AA} p \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

be a fully faithful 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 34) between small 𝒱\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 32).

Then for all c∈𝒞c \in \mathcal{C}

p *(Lan pc)≃c p^* (Lan_p c) \simeq c

and in fact the (Lan F⊣F *)(Lan_F \dashv F^*)-unit of an adjunction is a natural isomorphism

Id→≃p *∘Lan p. Id \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} p^* \circ Lan_{p} \,.
Proof

By the coend forumla (61) have naturally in d′∈𝒟d' \in \mathcal{D} the left Kan extension of any F:𝒞→𝒱F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} on the image of pp is

Lan pF:p(c)↦ ∫ c′∈C𝒟(p(c′),p(c))⋅F(c′) ≃∫ c′∈C𝒞(c′,c)⋅F(c′) ≃F(c), \begin{aligned} Lan_p F \;\colon\; p(c) \mapsto & \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), p(c)) \cdot F(c') \\ & \simeq \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{C}(c', c) \cdot F(c') \\ & \simeq F(c) \end{aligned} \,,
